verb.description: Represent (something) as being larger, better, or worse than it really is.
examples: he was apt to exaggerate any aches and pains
claims of turmoil within the firm are greatly exaggerated
I couldn't sleep for three days—I'm not exaggerating

origin: Mid 16th century: from Latin exaggerat- heaped up, from the verb exaggerare, from ex- thoroughly + aggerare heap up (from agger heap). The word originally meant pile up, accumulate, later intensify praise or blame, giving rise to current senses.
